sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Web Port to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: __PoolID
sci:arg.sci:help:
__PoolID is a case insensitive string that can optionally be set to optimize the speed of execution for quick running protocols. Multiple protocols with the same value for __PoolID can share expensive resources such as database connections, Java VMs, memory, etc. reducing the execution time by 1 to 2 seconds per run. This can give a large speed improvement to protocols that run in a few seconds such as web applications and interactive reports. Longer running protocols will not see much benefit. Generally, it is a good idea to use the same __PoolID for all protocols within a single application such as an interactive report since many of the components, databases, and data structures will be similar.

__PoolID can also be specified by the client when the protocol is launched. If __PoolID is specified both as a parameter by the client and as a parameter stored within the protocol, the client's value overrides the stored value.

To disable pooling entirely for this particular protocol, set __PoolID to <Disable>

sci:arg.name: Http Cookie Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Http Cookie Handling provides a mechanism to control the handling of Http cookies within components that access remote resources via Http and Https. These include the HTTP Connector, Data readers such as Text Reader, XML Reader (Generic), etc., and custom Java, Perl, and .Net components that use the available APIs for accessing remote servers. By default, New Protocols will have this setting enabled and set to "Protocol Scope". This means that Http cookies obtained from a remote server within any component in the protocol or any of its subprotocols will be parsed and appropriately sent back on subsequent requests from the same component or any other component. The handling of the cookies is based on the IETF standard as specified in http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6265. Setting the parameter to Disabled will prevent components from parsing and returning cookies to the remote servers.

Persistence of cookies is not supported, so scoping of Http cookies is entirely within the context of a single protocol execution.

Older protocols that do not have the Http Cookie Handling parameter will behave as though it had been set to "Disabled". To enable cookie handling in these protocols, copy this parameter from a New Protocol to the older protocol and set the parameter as desired.

sci:arg.name: __NotificationProtocol
sci:arg.sci:help:
__NotificationProtocol specifies the name or component ID (guid) of a protocol stored in the server's protocol database that will be executed when the current job completes. If your administrator has enabled notification protocols and depending on his or her preference, the notify protocol will either run as the anonymous user or as an admin specified user. The notification protocol receives several parameters that contain information about the original job:

  • Notify_JobID: The job id of the execution
  • Notify_JobStatus: A description of the result of the job execution
  • Notify_JobStatusCode: The status code that for the result of the job execution.
    • 5: Job was stopped by the client or administrator.
    • 6: Job completed normally with success.
    • 7: Job completed with an error.
    • 8: The process ID associated with the running job crashed or otherwise disappeared.
    • 9: Job failed to start.
  • Notify_ProtocolName: The name of the protocol
  • Notify_ProtocolPath: The path of the protocol in the DB. This field can be blank for protocols that were launched without saving to the database.
  • Notify_ProtocolLogName: The log name of the protocol. Is usually the same as ProtocolName, however this can be set by the client to a different name than the protocol.
  • Notify_RunHost: The name of the node where the protocol executed.
  • Notify_Username: The user that ran the job

sci:arg.sci:help: This group contains parameters specific to protocols containing Reporting components.

sci:arg.name: Reporting Stylesheet

sci:arg.name: Reporting Chart Display Type

sci:arg.name: Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: The Run On Grid parameter tells the server to run the protocol on the grid engine if the Pipeline Pilot server is configured to run with grid integration.

sci:arg.name: Queue Name

sci:arg.name: Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Grid Options allows you to specify options to the grid engine submit command. Leave blank to specify the default options.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Chart Data
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines groups of Data Series for the chart. There is no limit to the number of Data Series you can have. Use this parameter to add, remove and reorder data series in the chart.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1
sci:arg.sci:help: Settings for the Data Series to be plotted. You can add additional Data Series using Chart Data.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 X Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of a property on the data stream, or calculable property, to plot against the X axis.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Y Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of a property on the data stream, or calculable property, to plot against the Y axis. Multiple Y properties can be supplied with a comma-delimited list of property names.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Various data options for the data series.
sci:arg.sci:member: Data Series 1 Data Options Error Bar
Data Series 1 Data Options Y Axis for Plot
Data Series 1 Data Options Regression Line
Data Series 1 Data Options Regression Line Expression
Data Series 1 Data Options Legend Text

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options Error Bar
sci:arg.sci:help:
Optional parameter that is a property, or a PilotScript expression, providing values that describe the magnitude of error bars shown on individual bars. Any calculable properties must be calculated upstream.

Notes:

  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options Y Axis for Plot
sci:arg.sci:help: Select which Y axis to plot against (Y Axis or Second Y Axis).

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options Regression Line
sci:arg.sci:help: The type of regression line to draw in the chart. If "Custom", then the value of the "Regression Line Expression" parameter will be used to identify records whose values will be used to plot a regression line. If "Power", then all data points need to have positive values, otherwise the regression line will not be drawn.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options Regression Line Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
A PilotScript expression that evaluates to True for any data points that should be counted as part of a custom regression line. This parameter is ignored unless the Regression Line parameter's value is "Custom."

Notes:

  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options Label
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name of a property on the data stream, or a PilotScript expression, that will be displayed as a label next to each point in the chart.

Notes:

  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Data Options Legend Text
sci:arg.sci:help: Text to be displayed in the legend. If Y Property contains a single entry, then the specified string is used as the legend. If Y Property contains multiple entries then this parameter should contain a comma-separated list of strings to be used as legends. If this parameter is left blank, or the number of comma-separated strings is less than the number of Y Property entries then a default legend text will be supplied.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines
sci:arg.sci:help: Symbol and line attributes for the data series.
sci:arg.sci:member: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Type
Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Size
Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Color
Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Fill Pattern
Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Line Type
Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Line Thickness
Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Line Color

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Type
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the symbol type to use.

Notes:

  • You can assign a different symbol type for each data point by changing the parameter type to ExpressionType and setting its value to either the name of a property that holds a symbol type value or an expression defining a symbol type. A symbol type can be one of the predefined strings:
    • None
    • Square
    • Circle
    • Triangle
    • Inverted Triangle
    • Diamond
    • Cross
    • Star
    • Burst
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the symbol size. The entered value will be used as the number of pixels in the radius of the symbol. If the parameter is not specified the default symbol size of 6.0 is used.

Notes:

  • You can create bubble charts where the size of each data point reflects a meaningful aspect of the data by changing the parameter type to ExpressionType and typing an expression evaluating to a double value. If the expression is evaluated to a negative value, a symbol size of zero is used (no symbol is drawn).
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Color
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the symbol and error bar color.

Notes:

  • You can assign a different color for each data point by changing the parameter type to ExpressionType and setting its value to either the name of a property that holds a color value or an expression defining a color. There are three ways to specify colors for the property or expression:
    • Strings, e.g., Red or Blue.
    • RGB (reg-green-blue) color values (as hexadecimal values), prefixed with a '#' symbol. For example, to specify the color Red, use #FF0000.
    • Integer index values that correspond to the default order of colors from the Default Color Table. For example, to specify Yellow, use 4 (i.e., Yellow is the fourth entry in the table).
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Symbol Fill Pattern
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the symbol fill pattern to use.

Notes:

  • You can assign a different symbol fill pattern for each data point by changing the parameter type to ExpressionType and setting its value to either the name of a property that holds a symbol fill pattern value or an expression defining a symbol fill pattern. A symbol fill pattern can be one of the predefined strings:
    • Gradient
    • Solid
    • Open
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Line Type
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the line type for the data.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Line Thickness
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the thickness of line.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Symbols and Lines Line Color
sci:arg.sci:help: specifies the color of the line.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Links and Actions
sci:arg.sci:help: Links and Actions options for the data series.
sci:arg.sci:member: Data Series 1 Links and Actions Link
Data Series 1 Links and Actions Protocol Link
Data Series 1 Links and Actions HTML Attributes
Data Series 1 Links and Actions Tooltip
Data Series 1 Links and Actions Link Options

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Links and Actions Link
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional PilotScript expression evaluating to a link for each data point on the chart. The Link value can be an internal report link or an external URL.

  • Internal: A string that points to a Link Target in the report. Both the Link and Link Target values need to match for an internal link to work.
  • External: A string that points to an external URL such as 'http://www.sitename.com', 'ftp://www.sitename.com', or a file URL. A file URL can be in one of these forms:
    • 'file:///C:/.../scitegic root/.../document.pdf' - when using an absolute path within the Pipeline Pilot installation folder
    • 'file://///machine_name/C/.../document.pdf' - when using a Windows UNC path visible to the Pipeline Pilot server
    • 'file:///relative_path/document.pdf' - when using a path, relative to @SciTegicRoot
    • 'file://machine_name.domain_name.com/C/.../document.pdf' - when using a path with a fully qualified machine name

Notes:

  • If Y Property contains more than one entry, the same link will be assigned to relevant chart entries of all Y Properties.
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Links and Actions Protocol Link
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies a link that runs a protocol for each data point on the chart. Editing this parameter opens up the Protocol Link Dialog.

Note: if Y Property contains more than one entry, the same protocol link will be assigned to relevant chart entries of all Y Properties.

Notes:

  • If Y Property contains more than one entry, the same protocol link will be assigned to relevant chart entries of all Y Properties.
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Links and Actions Link Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how to display pages linked to data points. Applies only if Link or Protocol Link are set for the data series.

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Links and Actions Tooltip
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional property name, or PilotScript expression evaluating to a string, that will be displayed as a tooltip when the mouse hovers over a data point in the chart.

Notes:

  • If Y Property contains more than one entry, the same tooltip will be assigned to relevant chart entries of all Y Properties.
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Data Series 1 Links and Actions HTML Attributes
sci:arg.sci:help:
Defines attributes for one point on the chart. These attributes can be used by JavaScript code that is embedded in or included by the HTML report. One very common attribute is "id" which allows access to the element using the document.getElementById(id) method. Event handlers such as "onclick" and "onmouseover" are also common attributes.

Notes:

  • If Y Property contains more than one entry, the same attributes will be assigned to relevant chart entries of all Y Properties.
  • When working with array data in PilotScript expressions use the special property "CurrentArrayIndex" to access the array element that is currently being processed. For example, to multiply the values of the array property, "Foo", by 2, use:

    Foo[CurrentArrayIndex] * 2

    If you omit [CurrentArrayIndex], only the first element of the array will be used.

    If the PilotScript expression is just a property name, you do not need to use "CurrentArrayIndex".

sci:arg.name: Chart Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies attributes to be applied to the whole chart.
sci:arg.sci:member: Chart Options Force One Series per Data Record

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Title
sci:arg.sci:help: Title for the chart.
sci:arg.sci:value: $(Data Series 1 Y Property) vs. $(Data Series 1 X Property)

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies formatting to be applied to this element. Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog.

Depending on what this Format is being applied to, options may include:

  • Font settings (e.g., Color, Size, Bold, Italic, Underline)
  • Border settings (e.g., Color, Style, Width)
  • Background settings (Color, Image)
  • Alignment settings
  • etc.

Notes:

  • Only options that are relevant for this specific Format parameter will be displayed.
  • Background Image: Allows you to select a background image for the reporting element. This image must be accessible to the Pipeline Pilot server. For example, there are some example images in the apps\scitegic\generic\dataroot\data\Images folder in your Pipeline Pilot installation (shortcut is "generic\Images" folder). To use your own images, you need to upload them to a location such as your userdir or jobdir. An easy way to do this is to use the Binary Reader component to read the file, and the Binary Writer component to save it to the chosen location. Supported image types include .gif, .jpg, .png, and .bmp.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Position
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how this element is positioned. Editing this parameter opens the Position dialog, which enables you to change margins, paddings, width, and height.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Display Type
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the chart display format. This can be either interactive or a static image. If the Default option is selected then the server default setting as specified by the DefaultChartDisplayType global in the Admin portal is used.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Chart Output
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls how data records are plotted in charts:

  • If set to "One Chart for All Data Records" then all data records will be plotted in a single chart.
  • If set to "One Chart for Each Data Record" then each data record will be plotted in a separate chart. Use this when you want to create a chart for each row of a table. Note that with the "One Chart for Each Data Record" setting, this applies to all Data Series specified including any non-array data series.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: One Chart for All Data Records
One Chart for Each Data Record

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Force One Series per Data Record
sci:arg.sci:help:
Use this parameter to force each data record to be treated as separate data series. That is, when you want the values for X Property and Y Property in each data record to be treated as independent data series, so that they can be colored or sized differently, or use different symbols. This is typically done when X Property and Y Property contain array data.

Note that the effect of treating the data as separate data series will happen automatically if the first data record has array data, irrespective of the value for Force One Series per Data Record. But if the first data record has single values for X Property and Y Property (whether of type array or not), then this parameter must be set to True to force the data to be treated as separate data series. A typical use case is when the first data record has single values for X Property and Y Property but subsequent data records have array data.

  • False: The number of values of for X Property and Y Property determines whether each record creates a new data series.
  • True: Each data record always creates a separate data series.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Make Scriptable
sci:arg.sci:help:
Enables this chart for use with the Scriptable Charts API.

When this parameter is sent to true, all properties on the data stream will be stored in the chart for use with the Scriptable Charts API. If the data stream contains properties that should not be included, you can specify which properties to keep by placing a Keep Properties component upstream of the chart.

NOTE: Making the chart Scriptable will force the 'Display Type' to become 'Interactive'.

Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog. Options that can be changed by this parameter include Font, Font Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, and Color. You can also set the Background and Border Color of the legend.

Notes:

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Display Options Show Vertical Gridlines

sci:arg.sci:help: Apply a background color to the plot.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Display Options Plot Region Transparency
sci:arg.sci:help:
A transparency for rendering the plot region. Legal values are between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (fully opaque). The default is 1.0.

This options is not currently supported for PDF reports.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('The value has to be between 0.0 and 1.0'); Parameter() >= 0.0 AND Parameter() <= 1.0

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions
sci:arg.sci:member: Chart Options Links and Actions Link
Chart Options Links and Actions Link Target
Chart Options Links and Actions HTML Attributes
Chart Options Links and Actions Data Connector
Chart Options Links and Actions Protocol Link
Chart Options Links and Actions Link Options

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Link
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional parameter specifying a link for the reporting element produced by this component. The Link value can be an internal report link or an external URL.

  • Internal: A string that points to a Link Target in the report. Both the Link and Link Target values need to match for an internal link to work.
  • External: A string that points to an external URL such as 'http://www.sitename.com', 'ftp://www.sitename.com', or a file URL. A file URL can be in one of these forms:
    • 'file:///C:/.../scitegic root/.../document.pdf' - when using an absolute path within the Pipeline Pilot installation folder
    • 'file://///machine_name/C/.../document.pdf' - when using a Windows UNC path visible to the Pipeline Pilot server
    • 'file:///relative_path/document.pdf' - when using a path, relative to @SciTegicRoot
    • 'file://machine_name.domain_name.com/C/.../document.pdf' - when using a path with a fully qualified machine name

Example: To create a link from a combination of a property and static text, create a valid PilotScript expression. For example, if you have internal web pages linking to research projects that have addresses of the form: http://mydomain.com/ProjectID, where ProjectID is the actual project ID, and also a local property on the datastream, you would use:

'http://mydomain.com' . ProjectID

as the value for Link.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Protocol Link
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies a link that runs a protocol. Editing this parameter opens up the Protocol Link Dialog.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Link Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how to display pages linked to the reporting element. Applies only if Link or Protocol Link are set for the component.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Link Target
sci:arg.sci:help: Sets this element as the destination for links from other elements in the report. The value of Link Target can be text or a property name, and should match the value of Link in another report component. In the resulting report, when the element with Link is clicked, the element with the matching Link Target is brought to the top of the report page.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions HTML Attributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines attributes for the reporting element. These attributes can be used by JavaScript code that is embedded in or included by the HTML report. One very common attribute is "id" which allows access to the element using the document.getElementById(id) method. Event handlers such as "onclick" and "onmouseover" are also common attributes.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Data Connector
sci:arg.sci:help: Parameters related to the Data Connector interactivity model.
sci:arg.sci:member: Chart Options Links and Actions Data Connector Subscriber Event Handling
Chart Options Links and Actions Data Connector Publisher Subscriber Model

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Data Connector Publisher Subscriber Model
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether the component is a publisher, subscriber or both. Setting to 'None' bypasses any Data Connector node.

sci:arg.name: Chart Options Links and Actions Data Connector Subscriber Event Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Setting the on subscription event handling method.

Notes:
The publisher component always highlights.

sci:arg.name: X Axis Tickmark Options Tickmark Label Type
sci:arg.sci:help: The data type of the axis tickmark labels.

sci:arg.name: X Axis Tickmark Options Tickmark Label Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Selects the format of the tickmark labels displayed on this axis. The legal values are dependent on 'X Axis Tickmark Options Tickmark Label Type'. The default value is dependent on the label type, as indicated below.

The separator characters that appear in numbers are different around the world. The default number formatting will pick separators that are appropriate for the server's geographic location. In most places, a comma will be used to separate thousands in integers (e.g., 1,234) and a period used to separate whole and fractional parts of floating point numbers (e.g., 1.234). In Germany, these symbols are reversed. The separators can also be set by selecting the appropriate menu entry.

  • Integer:
    • Default - use the thousands separator appropriate for the geographic location
    • 1234 - AS IS
    • 1,234 - use a comma as a thousands separator
    • 1.234 - use a period as a thousands separator
  • Double:
    • Default - use a decimal point appropriate for the geographic location and output up to 8 digits after the point
    • 1.2 - use a period as a decimal point and output up to 1 digit after the point
    • 1.23 - use a period as a decimal point and output up to 2 digit after the point
    • 1.234 - use a period as a decimal point and output up to 3 digit after the point
    • 1.2345 - use a period as a decimal point and output up to 4 digit after the point
    • 1,2 - use a comma as a decimal point and output up to 1 digit after the point
    • 1,23 - use a comma as a decimal point and output up to 2 digit after the point
    • 1,234 - use a comma as a decimal point and output up to 3 digit after the point
    • 1,2345 - use a comma as a decimal point and output up to 4 digit after the point
    Note that in all of the above cases, the tickmarks label precision is based on the precision of the interval between tickmarks. For example, with a format of 1.234 and a tickmarks interval of 0.5, all tickmark values appear with a single decimal digit. Trailing zeros after the decimal point are always omitted, irrespective of the selected format.
  • DateTime:
    • Default - use the date and time format appropriate for the geographic location
    • 06/13/1960
    • 06/13/1960 13:23
    • 06/13/1960 13:23:45
    • 06/13/1960 1:23 PM (default)
    • 06/13/1960 1:23:45 PM
    • 13/06/1960
    • 13/06/1960 13:23
    • 13/06/1960 13:23:45
    • 13/06/1960 1:23 PM
    • 13/06/1960 1:23:45 PM
    • 06/13/60
    • 06/13/60 13:23
    • 06/13/60 13:23:45
    • 06/13/60 1:23 PM
    • 06/13/60 1:23:45 PM
    • 13/06/60
    • 13/06/60 13:23
    • 13/06/60 13:23:45
    • 13/06/60 1:23 PM
    • 13/06/60 1:23:45 PM
    • June 13, 1960
    • June 13, 1960 13:23
    • June 13, 1960 13:23:45
    • June 13, 1960 1:23 PM
    • June 13, 1960 1:23:45 PM
  • Date:
    • Default - use the date format appropriate for the geographic location
    • 06/13/1960
    • 13/06/1960
    • 06/13/60
    • 13/06/60
    • June 13, 1960

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates an XY plot for a report

Displays data as points and/or lines. Each incoming data record represents a single point for a given dataset. Multiple data series (i.e., Data Series 1, Data Series 2, etc.) can use distinct formatting. The chart as a whole and the individual axes are also customizable.

X Property is the property containing the X data values. Y Property is the property containing the Y data values. You can specify multiple Y properties for a given Data Series, as described below.

To plot multiple datasets in a single chart, add additional Data Series using Chart Data and specify an X Property and Y Property for Data Series 1 and Data Series 2, etc. This allows you to control formatting options individually for each data series. Alternatively, you can enter multiple properties as a comma-separated list in Y Property for a given Data Series. In this case, the same formatting is applied to each data property.

  • Data Series n: Specifies data properties and formatting options that control the particular data series.
  • Chart Options: Options that control the whole chart, such as Title and various Display Options.
  • X Axis: Options that control the look and feel of the X Axis.
  • Y Axis: Options that control the look and feel of the Y Axis.
  • Second Y Axis: Options that control the look and feel of a second Y Axis, displayed on the right side of the chart, when any Data Series is specified to be plotted against it.
  • Column Settings: Options to control how the chart appears inside a table.

Notes:

  • In Chart Options > Chart Output, you can specify if all data records are plotted in a single chart or in a separate chart for each data record, (e.g., to plot array data as a chart in each table row). Array data is not required.
  • To add additional Data Series, right-click the component to enter edit mode, and copy and paste one of the existing Data Series. Any values assigned to parameters are also copied.
  • To display some of your data in unique way, you can add Canvas Elements to an XY Chart. You can only pipe a Canvas Element into the chart when the Display Type is set to "Image".
  • To enable the Scriptable Charts API for this chart, set Chart Options > Make Scriptable to "True".

See Also:

  • Report Design Essentials
  • Chart Design
  • Canvas Elements Design
A data record representing the chart is sent to the pass port.
The input data records are all sent to the fail port.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: Link Options Mapping
sci:arg.sci:help: Mapping of the Format parameter name to the Link Options parameter name.
sci:arg.sci:value: Chart Options Links and Actions Link Options

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name or path name for the source data. The source can be a file, a network resource, a data record property, or a global property.

  • Use a file path name for files
  • Use a network URL for network resources
  • Use "global://property-name" for global properties

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called "SourceTag" is created and holds the value indicated.
- None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
- Filename: The name of the file read.
- FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
- FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
- ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
- Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
- Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
- KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader retains for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: UTF-8 Auto Detect
sci:arg.sci:help:
UTF-8 is a type of character encoding used to represent international characters with multiple bytes whereas basic Latin characters remain as a single byte. Files can be stored with a Byte Order Mark (BOM) to indicate that the type of character encoding.

When reading files that do not have a BOM, this parameter allows the reader to attempt to automatically detect UTF-8 encodings and convert as needed. However, be aware that automatic detection is not always reliable. In some cases, valid text stored in different character encodings can appear to be valid UTF-8. In these cases, the automatic detection will result in garbled text. When this occurs, you can consider using the Binary Reader to read the file, then converting using the Pilotscript function ConvertBytesToString

sci:arg.name: HasColumnNames
sci:arg.sci:help: When True, property names are taken from the first line of data in the file. When False, properties are named Column1,Column2, etc.

sci:arg.name: Delimiter
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the character that separates fields. Options include:
  • FigureOut: Determines the type automatically (looks for, in order: tab, comma, space, colon, semicolon).
  • Tab: For tab-delimited fields.
  • Space: For space-delimited fields.
  • Comma: For comma-delimited fields.
  • Colon: For colon-delimited fields.
  • Semicolon: For semicolon-delimited fields.
  • $: For fields delimited bty the "$" character.

sci:arg.name: MultipleValueDelimiter
sci:arg.sci:help: The delimiter to use between multiple values contained in a single property. If the multiple value delimiter exists in any of the input strings in any property, they are separated into an array of values. If "None", values are never separated into multiple values.

sci:arg.name: ParseNDimensionalArrayStrings
sci:arg.sci:help: Toggles whether to parse delimited N-Dimensional Array strings into N-Dimensional Array values.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: CommentLines
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of line numbers and line ranges to specify which lines should be ignored by the parser (column headers are read from the line that comes next).

sci:arg.name: UndefinedString
sci:arg.sci:help: Character or string to represent an undefined string read in the file. To make an empty string to be treated as an undefined value, set the parameter value to "EmptyString".

sci:arg.name: AllLines
sci:arg.sci:help: If True, all lines of the text file become part of a single data record. The values for a column from each row become multiple [array] values for the property (column).

sci:arg.name: TrimWhitespace
sci:arg.sci:help: Trims whitespace from the left and right ends of each value

sci:arg.name: CheckSyntax
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to perform a quick syntax check at the beginning of the file when it is opened, and if a problem is found, throw an error.

sci:arg.name: AddEmptyProperties
sci:arg.sci:help: If True, then if a row does not have as many values as the number of columns, the missing properties are added to the data record as empty properties

sci:arg.name: Join Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to merge the created data record onto the incoming data record. Options are:

  • OverwriteOrCreate: Copies all properties from the joining data onto the base data, overwriting the values of any properties that already exist.
  • OverwriteExisting: Copies only those properties from the joining data to the base data that already exist on the base.
  • CreateIfNew: Copies only those properties from the joining data to the base data that do not already exist on the base data.
  • AppendOrCreate: The value of a joining property that already exists in the base data is appended (as an array) to the value in the base property. The other joining properties that are not already present in the base data are copied there.
  • AppendExisting: The value of a joining property that already exists in the base data is appended (as an array) to the value in the base property. No other properties are copied.
  • Replace: The input data record is replaced by the created data record.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component that this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Reads data from text files containing one record per line with data separated by delimiters

The file or files are specified by Source. The file(s) should contain textual data formatted with a single record per line. Individual property values on each line should be separated by a delimiter character (such as, space, comma, tab), as specified by Delimiter.

If HasColumnNames is True, the values on the first line of the file are treated as the property names. Otherwise, Column1, Column2, and so on, are used as the property names.

Cells containing array data can be read by setting the MultipleValueDelimiter option to the character that separates the array elements. (Of course, this cannot be the same as the delimiter character.) You can now use the Unmerge Data component to unmerge these arrays into separate records. See Also:
  • The new, recommended component for Excel (.xlsx or .xls) files that does not require Excel to be installed on the server machine, and therefore is operational on Linux and Windows platforms - Excel Reader (Cross platform).
  • For non-delimited textual data, use Text Reader.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.
sci:arg.sci:value: Components\Data Access and Manipulation\File Readers\Delimited Text Reader

sci:arg.name: Parameter to Map
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of a parameter on the target protocol that this component's value should be mapped to.

sci:arg.name: Value
sci:arg.sci:help: This value from a record will be sent to the work protocol if the associated content is selected.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: p2mParameterName := StrReplace(ParameterName(), "Value", "Parameter To Map"); Parameter(p2mParameterName) EQ '' OR Parameter(ParameterName()) NOT EQ '';

sci:arg.name: Selected
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies if data records should be selected when the report loads. You can use this in three ways:

  • Set to a constant string, i.e., 'False' (include the single quotes), or 'True' to have all data records not selected, or selected, respectively
  • Provide the name of a property whose values evaluate to either TRUE or FALSE (anything other than TRUE will be false)
  • Provide any expression that will evaluate to a Boolean (True/False) value, such as PropX > 3

sci:arg.name: Highlight Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color for selected data items.

sci:arg.name: Data Record ID
sci:arg.sci:help:
Takes a property value and assigns an ID for each incoming data record.

This parameter can be used to link corresponding data records from distinct datastreams, feeding into multiple Data Connectors, that have the same value for Component ID.

Notes:

  • If the specified property contains duplicates, all data records having the same value will have the same ID and the selection of any one is equivalent to a selection of all corresponding data records
  • When a value for Data Record ID is specified, empty values for the property are ignored (i.e., those data records will not be linked across elements in the report)

sci:arg.name: Component ID
sci:arg.sci:help:
Assigns an ID that is used to connect multiple Data Connector components in a protocol, or across protocols deployed in SharePoint Web Parts. If only a single Data Connector is used, a value for this parameter is not necessary.

This parameter can also be used to create independent sets of interacting elements in a report. Simply specify a different value in each Data Connector component. Note that any downstream component (e.g., chart, table) can take input from a single Data Connector only.

sci:arg.name: Make Scriptable
sci:arg.sci:help: Enables programmatic interactivity with data connectors via the Scriptable Data Connector API. When using the API it is useful to specify a "Component ID" for this particular data connector component.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Adds data interactivity to a report

Enables interactivity between report elements by linking data streams for reporting components. Use a Data Connector upstream from any reporting component with output data. The Data Connector assigns an ID to each incoming data record, so all downstream reporting components become interactive.

You can connect all reporting components to a single Data Connector in the same protocol. The ID for each data record is assigned internally and no component parameterization is required. This method is ideal when there is a single stream of data to connect.

If your protocol includes multiple data streams, and data record order is inconsistent, use multiple Data Connector components instead. To properly connect the data records:

  • Set the Component ID parameter to connect instances of the Data Connectors;
  • Set the Data Record ID parameter to connect the data records themselves (see notes below).

Note that the first Data Connector with a given Component ID determines which records are selected when the report is loaded (i.e., the Selected parameter is only evaluated on the first Data Connector).

You can use this same combination of Component ID and Data Record ID parameters to connect data across protocol output in separate SharePoint Web Parts. When clicking data elements in report output, such as a column in a Histogram or a table row, end users are creating an "event" for which the other connected elements can then respond. Responses can be highlighted, filtered (i.e., only data items corresponding to the selected ones are shown), or reverse-filtered (items corresponding to selected ones are not-shown, all others are).

On each of the downstream interactive components, (e.g., charts, table, tiles), the interactivity behavior is specified via the Chart/Table Options > Links and Actions > Data Connector parameters.

Publisher Subscriber Model publishes and/or subscribes to events. Subscriber Event Handling highlights, filters, and reverse-filters.

For connectivity, use the following components with the Data Connector:

  • Area Chart
  • Bar Chart
  • Heat Map
  • Histogram (Categorical)
  • Histogram (Numerical)
  • Line Chart
  • Pie Chart
  • Radar Chart
  • XY Chart
  • XY Chart (Categorical X)
  • Canvas
  • Table
  • Interactive Table
  • Cross Tab
  • Tree
  • Bulleted List
  • Tile Horizontal and Tile Vertical (the default is to bypass data connector nodes)
  • Search Results (Documents and Text Collection)
  • Tag Cloud (Documents and Text Collection)

Notes:

  • Only Interactive Charts can be data connected. When connecting a chart to a Data Connector, set Chart Options > Display Type to "Interactive".
  • The interactive canvas is Flash-based. When connecting a canvas to a Data Connector, set Display Type to "Flash".
  • A component can only accept input from a single Data Connector, although the Data Connector does not need to be placed immediately upstream.
  • To enable the Scriptable Data Connector API for the component, set Make Scriptable to "True".

See Also:

  • Report Design Essentials
  • Interactive Reporting and Form Design
Data records containing the Data Connector information

sci:arg.name: Title
sci:arg.sci:help: The optional title of the HTML document. The title is also used as part of the report's file name.

sci:arg.name: Permanent URL
sci:arg.sci:help:
Display this protocol's starter URL in the browser address bar. Users will be able to bookmark the start protocol page that way.

Note: the protocol must be saved in Pipeline Pilot for this to work.

sci:arg.name: Theme
sci:arg.sci:help:
Choose a visual theme for the content.

To add a new theme: do not change this component. Just add a new subfolder to the ScitegicRoot\apps\saber\semantic\dataroot\data\assets\semantic\ file folder. The subfolder should contain a compiled customized copy of the Semantic UI distribution. The name of the subfolder should be alphanumeric and it cannot contain spaces or special characters.

sci:arg.name: Include Format and Position CSS
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to True, all native Pipeline Pilot format and position settings will be included in the output document. Otherwise all native Pipeline Pilot formatting will be ignored.

sci:arg.name: Add Page Margins
sci:arg.sci:help: When not using native Scitegic CSS, add page margins. This will add small margins on each side of the page. Scitegic styles already include this.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: not Parameter('Include Format and Position CSS');

sci:arg.name: Animate Link Underlines
sci:arg.sci:help: When hovering over a link, the link's underline is revealed by animating it out from the center.

sci:arg.name: Output Mode
sci:arg.sci:help:
Allows some alternative formatting and position settings to be used that may cause the HTML report output to behave and look more like the HTML generated with previous versions of Pipeline Pilot. This parameter is intended to be set on writers in protocols developed with previous versions of Pipeline Pilot where the output looks or behaves differently when run with the current version.

Always use the value of "Default" for new protocols or protocols under active development. The latest Reporting components may not behave correctly in HTML reports written with a non-default mode.

When set to "Pipeline Pilot 7.5", this parameter rolls back some of the improvements made in the name of standards compliance and formatting consistency, including:

  • The report will not include the HTML 4.01 Doctype declaration, which will cause Internet Explorer to render the report using quirks mode.
  • Position rules will not be strictly enforced, so Internet Explorer 6 will render borders and padding outside the specified width.
  • Horizontal alignment of block objects will not be supported, so you will not be able to, for example, center-align a table.
  • The page margins will not be set.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help: Lists the set of temporary files which will be converted by the network to true temporary file names

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help: Lists a set of properties (without the @) to be created on the property list for this protocol. Other properties are created on the global property list and so are accessible from all protocols.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When the network is run, whether we process once or until done for each process call

sci:arg.name: Accept Bootstrap
sci:arg.sci:help: Allow the use of Web Design (Bootstrap) collection components with the Semantic UI viewer? Generally speaking, this parameter should always be set to False to prevent the inadvertent mixing of the two frameworks.

sci:arg.name: Exclude Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-delimited list of properties which will not be rendered in an autogenerated table.

sci:arg.name: Column Order
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Header Text names (which may differ from the corresponding property names), indicating the order the columns should appear. Any non-listed properties will be added as subsequent columns.

Note:

  • The column names are case-sensitive

sci:arg.name: Show Entries Choices
sci:arg.sci:help: Choices on the "Show ... entries" pulldown menu above the table. The first choice is used to initially display the table. Use a comma to separate the choices.

sci:arg.name: Array Value Display
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines how array values are separated when they are displayed in an autogenerated table.

sci:arg.name: Data Connector
sci:arg.sci:help: Parameters related to the Data Connector interactivity model.

sci:arg.name: Publisher Subscriber Model
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether the component is a publisher, subscriber or both. Setting to 'None' bypasses any Data Connector node.

sci:arg.name: Subscriber Event Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Setting the on subscription event handling method.

Notes:
The publisher component always highlights.

sci:arg.name: Publisher Event Handling
sci:arg.sci:help: Setting the publishing event type.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-delimited list of global properties, each of which is automatically populated with the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, which always has a unique name.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold only the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top-level global property list and is accessible from all subprotocols, but breaks the encapsulation of the subprotocol and may collide with another property of the same name.

Therefore, you should always declare a new global property in the DeclareLocal parameter, to scope the global property to the subprotocol where it is used.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allows the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running locally or remotely. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option with care, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. Generally speaking, it yields improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (that is, server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be useful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of the maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Constant GUID
sci:arg.sci:help:
Override an automatically set GUID inside the component with this value.

If set, HTML element(s) will have their IDs set using this value instead of a randomly generated one.

Spaces or special characters are not allowed, only alphanumeric. The ID is case-sensitive.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails(ParameterName() . ' must be alphanumeric. Spaces or special characters are not allowed.'); numValues(rMatch(Parameter(), '[^a-zA-Z0-9]+', 'ig')) == 0;
